<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 238, 171, 248]]<|/det|> NUMBER <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 280, 170, 291]]<|/det|> **PHYSICS** <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 350, 311]]<|/det|> Paper 2 AS Structured Questions <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 280, 905, 291]]<|/det|> **9702/21** <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[784, 301, 905, 312]]<|/det|> **May/June 2012** <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[853, 322, 905, 333]]<|/det|> **1 hour** <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 341, 415, 353]]<|/det|> Candidates answer on the Question Paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 361, 368, 372]]<|/det|> No Additional Materials are required. <|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 394, 386, 405]]<|/det|> # READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 420, 718, 432]]<|/det|> Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 330, 446]]<|/det|> Write in dark blue or black pen. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 449, 608, 461]]<|/det|> You may use a soft pencil for any diagrams, graphs or rough working. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 463, 600, 475]]<|/det|> Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 477, 384, 488]]<|/det|> DO **NOT** WRITE IN ANY BARCODES. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 504, 256, 514]]<|/det|> Answer **all** questions. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 517, 764, 529]]<|/det|> You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 543, 600, 555]]<|/det|> At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 558, 652, 584]]<|/det|> The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 555, 905, 850]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 124, 87]]<|/det|>
## Data  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 102, 677, 560]]<|/det|>
speed of light in free space, \(c = 3.00\times 10^{8}\mathrm{m s}^{- 1}\) permeability of free space, \(\mu_{0} = 4\pi \times 10^{- 7}\mathrm{Hm}^{- 1}\) permittivity of free space, \(\epsilon_{0} = 8.85\times 10^{- 12}\mathrm{Fm}^{- 1}\) \((\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}} = 8.99\times 10^{9}\mathrm{mF}^{- 1})\) elementary charge, \(e = 1.60\times 10^{- 19}\mathrm{C}\) the Planck constant, \(h = 6.63\times 10^{- 34}\mathrm{Js}\) unified atomic mass constant, \(u = 1.66\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of electron, \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11\times 10^{- 31}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of proton, \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) molar gas constant, \(R = 8.31\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Avogadro constant, \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02\times 10^{23}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Boltzmann constant, \(k = 1.38\times 10^{- 23}\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\) gravitational constant, \(G = 6.67\times 10^{- 11}\mathrm{Nm}^{2}\mathrm{kg}^{- 2}\) acceleration of free fall, \(g = 9.81\mathrm{m s}^{- 2}\)

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 108, 558, 145]]<|/det|>
\[s = ut + \frac{1}{2} at^{2}\] \[\nu^{2} = u^{2} + 2as\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 163, 522, 180]]<|/det|>
\[W = \rho \Delta V\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 195, 536, 225]]<|/det|>
\[\phi = -\frac{Gm}{r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 235, 521, 252]]<|/det|>
\[p = \rho gh\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 262, 570, 295]]<|/det|>
\[p = \frac{1}{3}\frac{Nm}{V} < c^2 >\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 305, 536, 321]]<|/det|>
\[a = -\omega^2 x\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 339, 608, 375]]<|/det|>
\[\nu = \nu_{0}\cos \omega t\] \[\nu = \pm \omega \sqrt{(\chi_{0}^{2} - x^{2})}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 386, 536, 418]]<|/det|>
\[V = \frac{Q}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 426, 624, 445]]<|/det|>
\[1 / C = 1 / C_{1} + 1 / C_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 459, 592, 477]]<|/det|>
\[C = C_{1} + C_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 490, 528, 513]]<|/det|>
\[W = \frac{1}{2} QV\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 528, 592, 545]]<|/det|>
\[R = R_{1} + R_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 561, 624, 579]]<|/det|>
\[1 / R = 1 / R_{1} + 1 / R_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 594, 560, 610]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_{0}\sin \omega t\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 628, 580, 645]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_{0}\exp (-\lambda t)\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 655, 536, 689]]<|/det|>
\[\lambda = \frac{0.693}{t_{\frac{1}{2}}}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 383, 818, 400]]<|/det|>
The volume \(V\) of liquid that flows through a pipe in time \(t\) is given by the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 415, 535, 448]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{V}{t} = \frac{\pi Pr^4}{8Cl}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 467, 875, 501]]<|/det|>
where \(P\) is the pressure difference between the ends of the pipe of radius \(r\) and length \(l\). The constant \(C\) depends on the frictional effects of the liquid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 515, 411, 532]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 794, 875, 811]]<|/det|>
<form>base units of \(C\) .................................................... [3]

<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 875, 107]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 615, 875, 662]]<|/det|>
<pre>The uniform resistance wire XY has length \(1.00m\) and resistance \(4.0\Omega\) . Cell A has e.m.f. \(2.0V\) and internal resistance \(0.50\Omega\) . The current through cell A is \(I\) . Cell B has e.m.f. \(E\) and internal resistance \(r\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 676, 875, 708]]<|/det|>
<pre>The current through cell B is made zero when the movable connection J is adjusted so that the length of XJ is \(0.90m\) . The variable resistor R has resistance \(2.5\Omega\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 73, 846, 91]]<|/det|>
A laser is used to produce an interference pattern on a screen, as shown in Fig. 6.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 102, 858, 255]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[386, 274, 566, 292]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 6.1 (not to scale)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 305, 873, 354]]<|/det|>
The laser emits light of wavelength \(630\mathrm{nm}\). The slit separation is \(0.450\mathrm{mm}\). The distance between the slits and the screen is \(1.50\mathrm{m}\). A maximum is formed at \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and a minimum is formed at \(\mathsf{P}_2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 351, 800, 368]]<|/det|>
Interference fringes are observed only when the light from the slits is coherent.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 383, 180, 401]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 383, 500, 400]]<|/det|>
Explain what is meant by coherence.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 505, 180, 524]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 505, 643, 523]]<|/det|>
Explain how an interference maximum is formed at \(\mathsf{P}_1\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[845, 567, 875, 585]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 599, 181, 617]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 599, 636, 616]]<|/det|>
Explain how an interference minimum is formed at \(\mathsf{P}_2\).
